newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq denies that its oil flow faces obstructions.
newsitem.headline: Iraq denies that its oil flow faces obstructions.

text.p: Iraq's Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rasheed denied on Wednesday reports that the flow of Iraqi oil to Turkey was facing any political or technical problems.

"Iraq's oil minister denied the existence of any obstructions, whether political or technical, facing the flow of Iraqi oil to the Turkish terminal of Ceyhan," the official Iraqi news agency INA reported.
The minister described reports that Iraqi oil was blocked as dubious and biased "whose aim was to undermine the gains of the Iraqi people."

Official Iraqi media reported on Tuesday that President Saddam Hussein had pressed the button at a pumping station in the northern town of Kirkuk to restart the flow of Iraqi oil through a pipeline to Turkey after a break of six years caused by U.N. sanctions against Baghdad.
A Turkish pipeline official in Turkey told Reuters that Iraq had pumped a negligible amount of crude from Kirkuk on Tuesday but halted the process after a few hours for technical reasons.
The Turkish official said no Iraqi oil was being pumped to Turkey's Ceyhan port on Wednesday because it was not needed since the terminal's tanks had enough crude for a first load.
